articles.summary: Atmospheric carbon dioxide levels rose faster than ever last year, according to scientists. The rise is 'incompatible' with the goals set by the Paris Agreement. Last year's carbon dioxide emissions were twice the level consistent with the path to net zero and 1.5 degrees Celsius. The global average temperature set a new record last year.

articles.title: Canada Funds Climate Adaptation, Updates Flood Mapping
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Honourable Jonathan Wilkinson and Parliamentary Secretary Julie Dabrusin announced $4.1 million in funding for two projects based around Ontario's Great Lakes under Natural Resources Canada's Climate-Resilient Coastal Communities (CRCC) Program. The CRCC Program aims to support coastal communities around the Great Lakes by completing climate change risk assessments and developing integrated adaptation plans and actions.

articles.title: WA braces for second day of heatwave amidst power outages
articles.author: Holly Thompson
articles.summary: Parts of Western Australia came close to 50 degrees on Monday. Geraldton Airport hit 49.3 degrees, while in Perth, the mercury rose to 43.6 degrees. The suburb of Pearce was the metropolitan area's hottest suburb, reaching 45.5 degrees. A planned power outage in Dianella left many residents without airconditioning for several hours.

articles.title: Trump's Second Paris Accord Exit: A Global Repercussion
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Donald Trump has ordered the United States to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. The landmark agreement was signed by 196 nations and sets ambitious targets for limiting global warming and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Trump's administration argues the accords misalign with U.S. economic interests and sovereignty. Critics warn of the repercussions for global climate initiatives.

articles.title: Trump signs executive order directing US withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement — again
articles.author: MATTHEW DALY
articles.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order Monday directing the United States to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. In 2017, Trump announced that the U.S. would abandon the global Paris accord aimed at limiting long-term global warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit (1.5 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Trump's Renewed Paris Climate Agreement Withdrawal Sparks Global Concerns

articles.summary: Donald Trump announced the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement for the second time. The international community rallied to reaffirm their commitment to the agreement. articles.title: Trump signs executive order directing US withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement — again

articles.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order Monday directing the U.S. to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. The pact is aimed at limiting long-term global warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit (1.5 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial levels or less.

articles.title: Trump signs order on withdrawing U.S. from the Paris climate agreement again

articles.summary: President Donald Trump will withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement. It's a blow to worldwide efforts to combat global warming. The pact is aimed at limiting long-term global warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit (1.5 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial levels or keeping temperatures at least well below 3.6 degrees Celsius. The U.S. is one of the world's top carbon polluters.
